detail.content: Photography II for Non-majors: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Photography & Imaging About the Program Curriculum & Course Offerings In-House Resources Department Grants & Fellowships Gallery News & Events Alumni Directory of Faculty &amp; Administration Student Work ISOZine Facebook Twitter Instagram Blog  home > Photography & Imaging        Photography II for Non-majors  H82.1002 Studio 4 Credits Instructor(s): M. Baum       Tuesday, 2 p.m.-5:00 p.m. Call#: 71467                                 Pre-requisite:   Photo 1 for Non-Majors or by special permission.  Students will need a digital  SLR camera and a portable external hard drive of at least 250 GB. Students will also need to   purchase printing paper later in the term.                                     Photo 2 for NM is intended for students who have taken an analog photography  class such as Photo I for Non-majors but have limited or no experience with  digital photographic tools. In addition to a review of essential camera  theory and technique, this course will cover the fundamentals of digital  equipment and materials and embrace digital technology for its potential to  push photography's aesthetic and conceptual boundaries. Topics to be covered  include the use of a digital SLR, the basics of Adobe Photoshop as well as more  advanced techniques such as working with layers and masks, the power of RAW  files, making fine-art ink jet prints and film scanning. This class, however,  will not focus solely on technical training but will engage photography as a  means of visual communication, emphasizing an understanding of light and the  concept of “seeing photographically”. During the term, students will be  encouraged to initiate and sustain a focused project over an extended period of  time. Class time will be used for demonstration of new techniques,  supervised computer-lab sessions, group critique of student work as well as  looking at the work of photographic masters through slide lectures and video  screenings. While the materials we use to make pictures continue to  evolve, the visual awareness and thoughtfulness that it takes to make  successful photographs will never change. This course has a $350 nonrefundable lab fee. Summer Photography II: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Photography & Imaging About the Program Curriculum & Course Offerings In-House Resources Department Grants & Fellowships Gallery News & Events Alumni Directory of Faculty &amp; Administration Student Work ISOZine Facebook Twitter Instagram Blog  home > Photography & Imaging        Summer Photography II: Black & White and Color  SUMMER.H82.1002 Studio 4 Credits   Summer Section 001: MW 10-1:30 pm     Elaine Mayes Pre-requisite: Photography I or permission from the department. This course expands upon the principles and tools of Photography I to develop one’s own vision. An informal survey of different photographic techniques and aesthetics is explored through the use of slides so students can begin to “find their voice” as an artist/photographer. Students are expected to work on extended projects to develop an aesthetic and coherent photographic language. An emphasis is also placed on students refining their craft in relation to their ideas. Classes include weekly critiques of student work. Some basic materials are provided. Each student must have a camera with manually adjustable aperture and shutter speeds. This course is charged a lab fee of $332.00. Elaine Mayes studied photography and painting at the California School of Fine Arts (San Francisco Art Institute) with John Collier, Jr., Minor White, Richard Diebenkorn and Nathan Oliviera. She taught at the University of Minnesota, Hampshire College, Bard College, Pratt Institute, The Cooper Union and The International Center of Photography before beginning at NYU in 1983. Her solo exhibitions include the Marcuse Pfeifer Gallery, New York; Sandra Berler Gallery, Maryland; The Minneapolis Institute of Art; Rhode Island School of Design; the San Francisco Art Institute; Robert Burge Fine Arts, New York City; 7 International Fototage, Mannheim, Germany; the Museum of Contemporary Art in Honolulu and others. Represented in group exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art, New York; the Metropolitan Museum of Art; Corcoran Gallery; George Eastman House; The Dallas Museum of Fine Art; Seattle Art Museum; Photokina in Germany; the Katten Kabinet in Amsterdam; the Friends of Photography in San Francisco; the International Center of Photography in New York; the Boston Museum of Fine Arts and others. Elaine has had work published in Aperture, Modern Photography, Popular Photography, Art In America, MOJO Magazine, The New Yorker and in various books including her publication, "It Happened In Monterey," Britannia Press, 2002. She has received a Guggenheim Fellowship, three National Endowment for the Arts Fellowships, A New York State CAPS Fellowship, a Massachusetts Council on the Arts and Humanities Fellowship, an Atherton Foundation Fellowship, and an NYU Senior Faculty Development Grant. She has also been artist-in-residence at Lightwork, Syracuse University; and the Hui No'Eau Visual Arts Center in Makawao, Maui. She was Chair of the Department of Photography and Imaging from 1997 until retirement from teaching in 2001. Currently she is Professor Emerita.
